Question: After an effort begins, how long should it take to reach your maximum exhalation speed?
Answers: Immediately - as soon as the effort begins
FeedbackText: You should exhale as much as you can as fast as you can. As a result, you should reach your maximum exhalation speed immediately after starting the effort.

Question: When are you finished with an effort?
Answers: After you’ve blown as hard as you can
After all the air has been expelled from your lungs; at least 5 seconds
FeedbackText: An effort has been successfully completed after all the air has been expelled from your lungs. It may be an unfamiliar feeling, but it is important to empty your lungs during the effort.

Question: What should you do if you feel like coughing during the test?
Answers: Go ahead and cough; you can perform a make-up effort
FeedbackText: Don’t suppress your cough. If you need to cough, go ahead! Once the effort is over, continue the test like normal and one of the following efforts will replace the one which was interrupted by a cough.

Question: What should you do if you feel light-headed during the test?
Answers: Finish the effort, then sit down
Ignore it and continue the test
FeedbackText: If you feel light-headed, sit down immediately. After resting if you feel capable of continuing the test, you may do so with our approval. As a reminder, you are free to discontinue the test at any time.

Question: What should your posture be during the test?
Answers: Sitting upright where taking a deep breath is comfortable
FeedbackText: It is important to sit upright in a comfortable position which allows maximum airflow in and out of your lungs. Do your best not to slouch in your seat.

Question: During your test today, how do you think your lungs will perform compared to healthy peers of your same age, weight, and height?
FeedbackText:
We’ll provide you with some information about your lung function after we've finished today’s tests.

Good luck and thanks again for participating!
